title: Atoms from A to easy!

multiple-choice.question: What is the basic structure of an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: A nucleus made of positively charged electrons and neutrons, with negatively charged protons orbiting around it

options.label: B
options.text: A nucleus made of positively charged protons and neutrons, with negatively charged electrons orbiting around it

options.label: C
options.text: A nucleus made of negatively charged protons and electrons, with positively charged neutrons orbiting around it

options.label: D
options.text: A nucleus made of positively charged protons and neutrons, with negatively charged electrons and protons orbiting around it

multiple-choice.question: What is the diagonal rule used to determine the arrangement of electrons in an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: The diagonal rule shows the highest energy levels in an atom

options.label: B
options.text: The diagonal rule shows the lowest energy levels in an atom

options.label: C
options.text: The diagonal rule shows the order in which electrons fill the energy levels

options.label: D
options.text: The diagonal rule shows the number of electrons in each energy level

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between an electron configuration and valence electrons?

options.label: A
options.text: Electron configuration is the number of electrons in an atom, while valence electrons are the electrons in the outermost energy level

options.label: B
options.text: Electron configuration is the number of electrons in the outermost energy level, while valence electrons are the electrons in the inner energy levels

options.label: C
options.text: Electron configuration is the arrangement of electrons in an atom, while valence electrons are the electrons in the highest energy level

options.label: D
options.text: Electron configuration is the number of electrons in the highest energy level, while valence electrons are the electrons in the inner energy levels

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when an atom gains or loses electrons to form ions?
What is the result of the process of ionic bonding between magnesium and chlorine?
What is the empirical formula of magnesium chloride?
What is the name of the compound MgCl2?
What is the use of magnesium in the process of making tofu?

options.label: D
options.text: Not used in the process of making tofu

multiple-choice.question: What is the characteristic of magnesium that makes it useful in certain applications?
What is the term used to describe the ratio of atoms in a compound?

title: Dark matter: The matter we can't see - James Gillies

multiple-choice.question: What was the basic idea of the ancient Greek theory of the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe is made up of a single element.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe is simple and can be explained by four basic elements: earth, air, fire, and water.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is made up of tiny, indivisible bits of stuff called atoms.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe is infinite and has no beginning or end.

multiple-choice.question: Who came up with the idea that everything we see is made up of tiny, indivisible bits of stuff called atoms?
What percentage of the universe is made up of ordinary matter, such as atoms?
What is the term used to describe the invisible matter that makes up most of the universe?
What is the best evidence for the existence of dark matter?

options.label: A
options.text: Measurements of the cosmic microwave background

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the energy that is thought to be driving the acceleration of the universe's expansion?
What percentage of the universe is thought to be made up of dark energy?
What is the theory that predicts the existence of a whole range of new particles that could make up dark matter?
What is the idea that the universe must be simple, and that all the universe's diversity stems from a single element?

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that the universe began with four basic elements

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the afterglow of the Big Bang?

title: What happened to antimatter? - Rolf Landua

multiple-choice.question: According to the famous physics formula E = mc^2, what is the relationship between mass and energy?

options.label: C
options.text: Mass and energy are interchangeable like two currencies.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a huge amount of energy is concentrated in a tiny space?
What is the relationship between particles and their antiparticles?

options.label: A
options.text: Particles are always heavier than their antiparticles.

options.label: B
options.text: Particles are always lighter than their antiparticles.

options.label: C
options.text: Particles and their antiparticles are always produced in equal amounts.

options.label: D
options.text: Particles and their antiparticles are always produced in unequal amounts.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if a marble and an antimarble were brought together?

options.label: A
options.text: They would combine to form a new particle.

options.label: B
options.text: They would combine to form a new substance.

options.label: C
options.text: They would completely disappear into a big flash of energy.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we use antimatter for energy production?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's too expensive to produce.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's too difficult to harness.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it takes a billion times more energy to make antimatter than you get back.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not available in nature.

multiple-choice.question: What is the mystery surrounding antimatter?

options.label: A
options.text: There is too much antimatter in the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: There is too little antimatter in the universe.

options.label: C
options.text: Antimatter is not available in nature.

options.label: D
options.text: Antimatter is not useful for energy production.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the antimatter in the universe after the Big Bang?

options.label: C
options.text: It was preserved in equal amounts with matter.

options.label: D
options.text: It was not present in the universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the asymmetry between matter and antimatter?

options.label: A
options.text: It is due to a tiny imbalance in the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: It is due to a random event in the Big Bang.

options.label: C
options.text: It is due to an unknown cause that is still being researched.

options.label: D
options.text: It is due to a known cause that has been proven.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the energy content of antimatter?

options.label: A
options.text: It is lower than conventional fuel.

options.label: B
options.text: It is higher than conventional fuel.

options.label: C
options.text: It is equal to conventional fuel.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not useful for energy production.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential of antimatter for energy production?

options.label: A
options.text: It is limited due to its high cost.

options.label: B
options.text: It is unlimited due to its high energy content.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not possible due to its rarity.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not possible due to its instability.

title: Big Data - Tim Smith

multiple-choice.question: What is big data?

options.label: A
options.text: A concept used in physics to study the behavior of particles

options.label: B
options.text: A large amount of digital information that is difficult to store, transport, or analyze

options.label: C
options.text: A type of computer programming language

options.label: D
options.text: A method of data analysis used in business

multiple-choice.question: Which organization has been dealing with the challenge of big data for decades?
In the 1970s, how was big data distributed across different sets of computers at CERN?

options.label: A
options.text: It was stored in a single computer

options.label: B
options.text: It was distributed across different sets of computers, which were joined together in dedicated networks

options.label: C
options.text: It was stored in a cloud

options.label: D
options.text: It was analyzed using a mainframe computer

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for adopting the internet working standard at CERN in the 1980s?

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate remote access to big data

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the cost of computing

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the speed of data analysis

multiple-choice.question: What was created in the early 1990s to make it easy for physicists to share their findings with colleagues?
Why did CERN start distributing petabytes of data to collaborating partners in the early 2000s?

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the cost of computing

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze big data more efficiently

options.label: D
options.text: Because the data was too large to be stored on a single computer

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the grid model and cloud computing?

options.label: A
options.text: The grid model is more secure, while cloud computing is less secure

options.label: B
options.text: The grid model is more business-like, while cloud computing is more community-based

options.label: C
options.text: The grid model is more expensive, while cloud computing is less expensive

options.label: D
options.text: The grid model is more efficient, while cloud computing is less efficient

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of big data in various fields?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for more efficient data storage

options.label: B
options.text: It enables more accurate data analysis

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for the derivation of more knowledge by joining related information together and spotting correlations

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the cost of computing

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a field that is turning to gathering big data?
What is the challenge facing researchers in the field of big data?

options.label: A
options.text: To store and transport big data

options.label: B
options.text: To analyze big data more efficiently

options.label: C
options.text: To invent new tools and techniques to mine vast stores of big data

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the cost of computing

title: How did feathers evolve? - Carl Zimmer

multiple-choice.question: What are some remarkable features of feathers?

options.label: B
options.text: They are gorgeous in their complexity, delicate in their construction, and strong enough to hold a bird thousands of feet in the air.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only found on birds.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not very useful for birds.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how did the first feathers of birds evolve?
What is the main function of feathers in birds?
What did paleontologists find in the late 1990s that supported the idea that birds are living dinosaurs?
How did scientists determine that dinosaurs with feathers were related to birds?
What is the name of the small bird-like dinosaur mentioned in the transcript?
According to the transcript, what was the likely function of feathers in early feathered dinosaurs?

options.label: C
options.text: To provide extra lift for running.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the molecule that gives feathers their color?

options.label: A
options.text: By flapping their arms as they ran up an incline.

options.label: B
options.text: By using their long tails to balance.

options.label: C
options.text: By using their strong legs to jump.

options.label: D
options.text: By using their sharp beaks to fly.

multiple-choice.question: How long after the first wiry feathers evolved did feathers lift dinosaurs into the sky?

title: How to start a movement

multiple-choice.question: What is the crucial role of the first follower in a movement?

options.label: A
options.text: To lead the group and make decisions

options.label: B
options.text: To show everyone else how to follow

options.label: A
options.text: Leadership is the key to success

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of nurturing your first few followers

options.label: C
options.text: Leadership is over-glorified and followers are just as important

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Because those who were sitting on the fence before now have no reason not to join

options.text: Because the movement becomes more radical and extreme

options.label: C
options.text: When the movement becomes public and gains momentum

options.label: D
options.text: When the movement reaches its final goal

options.label: B
options.text: To follow the leader without questioning

options.label: C
options.text: To emulate the followers and not the leader

options.label: D
options.text: To take charge of the movement

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are not as charismatic as the leader

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not as influential as the leader

options.label: C
options.text: Because it takes guts to stand out like that

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not as well-organized as the leader

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of showing not just the leader but the followers in a movement?

options.label: A
options.text: To show the leader's charisma and influence

options.label: B
options.text: To show the followers' dedication and commitment

options.label: C
options.text: To show that new followers emulate the followers, not the leader

options.label: D
options.text: To show the movement's structure and organization

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to starting a movement?

options.label: B
options.text: To have the courage to follow and show others how to follow

options.label: C
options.text: To have a clear vision and goal

options.label: D
options.text: To have a lot of resources and funding

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the crowd in a movement?

options.label: B
options.text: To follow the leader without questioning

options.label: C
options.text: To make the movement public and gain momentum

options.label: D
options.text: To take charge of the movement

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the real lesson from the movement?

options.label: A
options.text: Leadership is the key to success

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of nurturing your first few followers

options.label: C
options.text: Leadership is over-glorified and followers are just as important

options.label: D

title: How do you know whom to trust? - Ram Neta

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary source of our knowledge about the world around us?
What can happen when we appeal to authority, even if the authority is highly respected?

options.label: A
options.text: We gain knowledge and always make the right decisions

options.label: B
options.text: We gain knowledge, but may make mistakes

options.label: C
options.text: We never gain knowledge and always make mistakes

options.label: D
options.text: We never gain knowledge, but may make mistakes

multiple-choice.question: Why might a highly respected authority turn out to be wrong?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are overlooking important evidence

multiple-choice.question: What is the most useful thing to consider when deciding whether to trust the testimony of an authority?

options.label: B
options.text: Their track record on a particular topic

multiple-choice.question: Why is it useful to consider an authority's track record on a particular topic?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it helps us to understand their qualifications and credentials

options.label: B
options.text: Because it helps us to determine whether they are honest or dishonest

options.label: C
options.text: Because it helps us to predict their future performance

options.label: D
options.text: Because it helps us to understand their personal opinions and biases

multiple-choice.question: How can we judge our own instincts by their track record?

options.label: A
options.text: By considering how often we make mistakes

options.label: B
options.text: By considering how often we make correct decisions

options.label: C
options.text: By considering our qualifications and credentials

options.label: D
options.text: By considering our social status and reputation

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of considering an authority's track record when deciding whether to trust their testimony?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps us to gain knowledge and make the right decisions

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us to avoid making mistakes and losing money

options.label: C
options.text: It helps us to understand the authority's qualifications and our own biases and opinions

multiple-choice.question: Why might a respected economist turn out to be wrong?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are overlooking important evidence

multiple-choice.question: What can happen if we trust the testimony of an authority who has a poor track record on a particular topic?

options.label: A
options.text: We will gain knowledge and make the right decisions

options.label: B
options.text: We will lose money and make mistakes

options.label: C
options.text: We will understand the authority's and our own biases and opinions

options.label: D
options.text: We will become experts in the field

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to distinguish between occasions when we can safely and reasonably trust authority and occasions when we can't?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it helps us to gain knowledge and make the right decisions

options.label: B
options.text: Because it helps us to avoid making mistakes and losing money

options.label: C
options.text: Because it helps us to understand the authority's and our own biases and opinions

title: Pool medical patents, save lives - Ellen 't Hoen

multiple-choice.question: What was the main issue that the U.S. government faced in the early 20th century regarding the production of military airplanes?

options.label: C
options.text: Patent wars between companies holding patents on essential parts of the airplane

options.label: D
options.text: A conflict with other countries over trade agreements

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the U.S. government's decision to force patent holders to make their patents available to others?

options.label: A
options.text: The production of military airplanes decreased

options.label: C
options.text: The production of military airplanes increased, and the prices decreased

options.label: D
options.text: The U.S. government lost control over the production of military airplanes

multiple-choice.question: What was the main issue that Nelson Odoma faced in 2002 when he discovered he had HIV?

options.label: B
options.text: He couldn't access the treatment in his country

options.label: C
options.text: He didn't know he had HIV

options.label: D
options.text: He didn't want to take the treatment

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the establishment of the medicines patent pool in 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: The prices of antiretroviral medicines increased

options.label: B
options.text: The production of antiretroviral medicines decreased

options.label: C
options.text: The prices of antiretroviral medicines decreased, and the production increased

options.label: D
options.text: The medicines patent pool was not effective in reducing the prices of antiretroviral medicines

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the airplane patent pool and the medicines patent pool?

options.label: A
options.text: The airplane patent pool is voluntary, while the medicines patent pool is mandatory

options.label: B
options.text: The airplane patent pool is mandatory, while the medicines patent pool is voluntary

options.label: C
options.text: The airplane patent pool is used for military airplanes, while the medicines patent pool is used for antiretroviral medicines

options.label: D
options.text: The airplane patent pool is used for antiretroviral medicines, while the medicines patent pool is used for military airplanes

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of the medicines patent pool in relation to the new four-in-one AIDS medication approved by the U.S. drug agency in August of this year?

options.label: A
options.text: The medicines patent pool has not yet licensed the intellectual property for the new medication

options.label: B
options.text: The medicines patent pool is working with generic manufacturers to make the new medication available at low cost

options.label: C
options.text: The medicines patent pool has licensed the intellectual property for the new medication, but it is not yet available

options.label: D
options.text: The medicines patent pool is not involved in the development of the new medication

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why generic manufacturers may be scared away from developing new medicines?

options.label: A
options.text: The high cost of developing new medicines

options.label: B
options.text: The complexity of the regulatory process

options.label: C
options.text: The patent landscape, which can be difficult to navigate

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of funding for research and development

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the medicines patent pool?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the prices of antiretroviral medicines

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the production of antiretroviral medicines

options.label: C
options.text: To make antiretroviral medicines available at low cost to people in need

options.label: D
options.text: To promote the development of new antiretroviral medicines

options.label: A
options.text: Nelson Odoma is a member of the expert advisory group of the medicines patent pool

options.label: B
options.text: Nelson Odoma is the director of the medicines patent pool

options.label: C
options.text: Nelson Odoma is a patent holder who has licensed his intellectual property to the medicines patent pool

options.label: D
options.text: Nelson Odoma is a generic manufacturer who works with the medicines patent pool

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of the medicines patent pool for Nelson Odoma and his son?

options.label: A
options.text: The medicines patent pool will increase the prices of antiretroviral medicines

options.label: B
options.text: The medicines patent pool will decrease the production of antiretroviral medicines

options.label: C
options.text: The medicines patent pool will make antiretroviral medicines available at low cost to Nelson Odoma and his son

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the method used to multiply numbers close to the powers of 10, like 10, 100, 1,000, and so on?

When squaring 101, we add plus sides to get 102, and then square 01 to get 01. What is the result of 101 squared?
According to the transcript, how many sutras (or word formulas) are there in Vedic math?
In the vertically and crosswise sutra, we first multiply vertically, then go crosswise, and then do vertical again. What is the result of 2 times 1 in this sutra?

In the vertically and crosswise sutra, we multiply 3 times 2 to get 6. What is the result of 6 plus 4?
When multiplying 4 times 2 using the vertically and crosswise sutra, we get 8. What is the result of 8 plus 6?
